The ongoing impacts of these Swiss tax reform law changes became effective January 1, 2020. See Note 16, Income Taxes , for more information.

## Summary of Results

- Net revenues were approximately $28.7 billion in 2021 and $26.6 billion in 2020, an increase of 8.0% in 2021 and an increase of 2.8% in 2020. In 2021, our net revenue growth continued to reflect increased demand for most of our snack category products in both our emerging and developed markets relative to 2020, though some markets were not yet back to pre-pandemic levels. In developed markets, increased food purchases for in-home consumption continued to drive net revenue growth, partially offset by declines in some markets as they lapped prior-year strong volume growth resulting from increased consumer demand due to the pandemic. In emerging markets, we lapped the negative initial impacts we experienced from the pandemic in 2020, with strong revenue growth in 2021 across most of our key markets, though some markets remained challenged. In addition, our out-of-home consumption businesses, which experienced significant negative impacts from the pandemic in 2020, continued to recover, particularly our gum and candy, foodservice and world travel retail businesses.
- -Net revenues increased in 2021, driven by favorable volume/mix, higher net pricing, a significant impact from favorable currency translation, as most currencies we operate in strengthened against the U.S. dollar compared to exchange rates in the prior year, and incremental net revenues from our acquisitions of Gourmet Foods, Grenade and Hu in 2021 and Give & Go in 2020.
- -Net revenues increased in 2020, driven by higher net pricing, favorable volume/mix and incremental net revenues from our acquisitions of Give & Go in 2020 and Perfect Snacks in 2019. These items were partially offset by the significant impact of unfavorable currency translation, as the U.S. dollar strengthened against most currencies in which we operate compared to exchange rates in the prior year, as well as the May 28, 2019 divestiture of most of our cheese business in the Middle East and Africa.
- Organic Net Revenue increased 5.2% to $28.0 billion in 2021 and increased 3.7% to $26.8 billion in 2020. Organic Net Revenue increased in both 2021 and 2020 due to favorable volume/mix and higher net pricing, despite impacts from the COVID-19 pandemic described above. Organic Net Revenue is on a constant currency basis and excludes revenue from acquisitions and divestitures. We use Organic Net Revenue as it provides improved year-over-year comparability of our underlying operating results (see the definition of Organic Net Revenue and our reconciliation with net revenues within Non-GAAP Financial Measures appearing later in this section).
- Diluted EPS attributable to Mondelēz International increased 23.1% to $3.04 in 2021 and decreased 8.2% to $2.47 in 2020.
- -Diluted EPS increased in 2021 primarily driven by an increase in Adjusted EPS, lapping prior-year costs associated with the JDE Peet's transaction, favorable year-over-year mark-to-market impacts from currency and commodity derivatives, lower intangible asset impairment charges, lapping the prioryear loss on interest rate swaps, lower losses on debt extinguishment and related expenses, lower Simplify to Grow program costs and a net benefit from acquisition integration costs and contingent consideration adjustments. These factors were partially offset by a lower gain on equity method investment transactions, higher initial impacts from enacted tax law changes, lower net earnings from divestitures, lapping the prior-year benefit from the resolution of tax matters and higher impact from pension participation changes.
- -Diluted EPS decreased in 2020 primarily driven by lapping the prior-year benefit from initial impacts from enacted tax law changes, costs associated with the JDE Peet's transaction, loss on debt extinguishment, unfavorable year-over year change in equity method investee items, higher intangible asset impairment charges, unfavorable year-over-year mark-to-market impacts from currency and commodity derivatives, lapping a prior-year gain on divestiture and lapping the prior-year benefit from pension participation changes. These factors were partially offset by gains on equity method investment transactions, higher Adjusted EPS, favorable change from the resolution of tax matters (a benefit in 2020 as compared to an expense in 2019), lower Simplify to Grow program costs and lower losses related to interest rate swaps.

Based on these Federal / Cantonal events, our position is the enactment of Swiss tax reform for U.S. GAAP purposes was met as of September 30, 2019, and we recorded the impacts in the third quarter 2019. The net impact was a benefit of $767 million, which consisted of a $769 million reduction in deferred tax expense from an allowed step-up of intangible assets for tax purposes and remeasurement of our deferred tax balances, partially offset by a $2 million indirect tax impact in selling, general and administrative expenses. The ongoing impacts of these Swiss tax reform law changes became effective January 1, 2020. See Note 16, Income Taxes , for more information.

## Summary of Results

- Net revenues were approximately $28.7 billion in 2021 and $26.6 billion in 2020, an increase of 8.0% in 2021 and an increase of 2.8% in 2020. In 2021, our net revenue growth continued to reflect increased demand for most of our snack category products in both our emerging and developed markets relative to 2020, though some markets were not yet back to pre-pandemic levels. In developed markets, increased food purchases for in-home consumption continued to drive net revenue growth, partially offset by declines in some markets as they lapped prior-year strong volume growth resulting from increased consumer demand due to the pandemic. In emerging markets, we lapped the negative initial impacts we experienced from the pandemic in 2020, with strong revenue growth in 2021 across most of our key markets, though some markets remained challenged. In addition, our out-of-home consumption businesses, which experienced significant negative impacts from the pandemic in 2020, continued to recover, particularly our gum and candy, foodservice and world travel retail businesses.
- -Net revenues increased in 2021, driven by favorable volume/mix, higher net pricing, a significant impact from favorable currency translation, as most currencies we operate in strengthened against the U.S. dollar compared to exchange rates in the prior year, and incremental net revenues from our acquisitions of Gourmet Foods, Grenade and Hu in 2021 and Give & Go in 2020.
- -Net revenues increased in 2020, driven by higher net pricing, favorable volume/mix and incremental net revenues from our acquisitions of Give & Go in 2020 and Perfect Snacks in 2019. These items were partially offset by the significant impact of unfavorable currency translation, as the U.S. dollar strengthened against most currencies in which we operate compared to exchange rates in the prior year, as well as the May 28, 2019 divestiture of most of our cheese business in the Middle East and Africa.
- Organic Net Revenue increased 5.2% to $28.0 billion in 2021 and increased 3.7% to $26.8 billion in 2020. Organic Net Revenue increased in both 2021 and 2020 due to favorable volume/mix and higher net pricing, despite impacts from the COVID-19 pandemic described above. Organic Net Revenue is on a constant currency basis and excludes revenue from acquisitions and divestitures. We use Organic Net Revenue as it provides improved year-over-year comparability of our underlying operating results (see the definition of Organic Net Revenue and our reconciliation with net revenues within Non-GAAP Financial Measures appearing later in this section).
- Diluted EPS attributable to Mondelēz International increased 23.1% to $3.04 in 2021 and decreased 8.2% to $2.47 in 2020.
- -Diluted EPS increased in 2021 primarily driven by an increase in Adjusted EPS, lapping prior-year costs associated with the JDE Peet's transaction, favorable year-over-year mark-to-market impacts from currency and commodity derivatives, lower intangible asset impairment charges, lapping the prioryear loss on interest rate swaps, lower losses on debt extinguishment and related expenses, lower Simplify to Grow program costs and a net benefit from acquisition integration costs and contingent consideration adjustments. These factors were partially offset by a lower gain on equity method investment transactions, higher initial impacts from enacted tax law changes, lower net earnings from divestitures, lapping the prior-year benefit from the resolution of tax matters and higher impact from pension participation changes.
- -Diluted EPS decreased in 2020 primarily driven by lapping the prior-year benefit from initial impacts from enacted tax law changes, costs associated with the JDE Peet's transaction, loss on debt extinguishment, unfavorable year-over year change in equity method investee items, higher intangible asset impairment charges, unfavorable year-over-year mark-to-market impacts from currency and commodity derivatives, lapping a prior-year gain on divestiture and lapping the prior-year benefit from pension participation changes. These factors were partially offset by gains on equity method investment transactions, higher Adjusted EPS, favorable change from the resolution of tax matters (a benefit in 2020 as compared to an expense in 2019), lower Simplify to Grow program costs and lower losses related to interest rate swaps.

questions.question: The Health Care segment shows 4% volume growth excluding acquisitions and divestitures, yet reports 10% organic sales growth. What specific factors contribute to this difference, and what does it suggest about the segment's internal growth dynamics?
questions.answer: The Health Care segment achieved 4% volume growth excluding acquisitions and divestitures, indicating internal volume expansion. Additionally, the segment realized 3% growth from pricing and 3% from mix effects, contributing to a total of 10% organic sales growth. This suggests that the segment's growth is not solely volume-driven but also benefits from pricing power and favorable product mix, indicating strong internal growth capabilities and potential market leadership in selected categories.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: PG(page_26) → Volume Excl Acq&Div: PG reports 4% volume growth for the Health Care segment, excluding acquisitions and divestitures, indicating internal volume performance.
Hop 2: Volume Excl Acq&Div → Health Care: The 4% volume growth is a key component of the Health Care segment's overall growth profile.
Hop 3: Health Care ← PG(page_36): PG reports 10% organic sales growth for the Health Care segment, which incorporates volume, pricing, and mix effects.

questions.question: How does the $246 million pre-tax charge related to Saudi Arabia customs assessments in 2021 impact the consolidated net revenues growth of $3.4 billion reported for the year ended December 31, 2023, especially considering that the charge was recorded as a reduction in net revenues for the SSEA, CIS & MEA segment?
questions.answer: The $246 million pre-tax charge related to Saudi Arabia customs assessments in 2021, which was recorded as a reduction in net revenues for the SSEA, CIS & MEA segment, directly impacted the base year comparison for PMI's consolidated net revenues. This reduction in 2021 revenues influenced the year-over-year growth calculation, meaning that the $3.4 billion increase in net revenues reported for 2023 must be viewed in the context of prior-year charges that lowered the comparative base. While the 2023 results show strong growth (10.7%), the prior-year customs charge contributed to a lower starting point, thereby amplifying the apparent growth in 2023. This chain of impact illustrates how discrete regulatory and customs events in specific markets can shape multi-year financial performance trends.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [PM](page_118) → [Saudi Arabia Customs Assessments]: PM recorded a $246 million pre-tax charge in 2021 related to customs duties in Saudi Arabia, which was recorded as a reduction in net revenues for combustible tobacco products in the SSEA, CIS & MEA segment.

Hop 2: [Saudi Arabia Customs Assessments] → [Net Revenues]: The customs charge was directly recorded as a reduction in net revenues, affecting the segment's financial performance and the comparative base for future revenue growth analysis.

Hop 3: [Net Revenues] ← [PM](page_30): In 2023, PM reported net revenues of $35.2 billion, representing a $3.4 billion (10.7%) increase from 2022, with segment-level dynamics (including SSEA, CIS & MEA) influencing overall growth.

- Charges	related	to	the	war	in	Ukraine -	See	Note	4. War	in	Ukraine for	details	of	the	$53	million	and	$151	million	pre-tax charges	in	the	Europe	segment	for	the	years	ended	December	31,	2023	and	2022,	respectively.
- Swedish	Match	AB	acquisition	accounting	related	item -	See Note	3.	Acquisitions for	details	of	the	$18	million	and	$125 million	 pre-tax	 purchase	 accounting	 adjustments	 related	 to	 the	 sale	 of	 acquired	 inventories	 stepped	 up	 to	 fair	 value included	in	the	Swedish	Match	segment	for	the	years	ended	December	31,	2023	and	2022,	respectively.
- Asset	impairment	and	exit	costs -	See	Note	20. Asset	Impairment	and	Exit	Costs for	details	of	the	$109	million	and	$216 million	pre-tax	charges	for	the	year	ended	December	31,	2023	and	2021,	respectively,	as	well	as	a	breakdown	of	these	costs by	segment.
- Termination	of	agreement	with	Foundation	for	a	Smoke-Free	World -On	September	29,	2023,	PMI	and	the	Foundation	for	a Smoke-Free	 World	 (the	 "Foundation")	 entered	 into	 the	 Final	 Grant	 Agreement	 and	 Termination	 of	 the	 Second	 Amended	 and Restated	Pledge	Agreement	("Agreement").	Under	the	terms	of	the	agreement,	PMI	paid	$140	million	in	the	third	quarter	of 2023	in	return	for	the	termination	of	the	pledge	agreement	between	the	parties.	As	a	result,	in	the	third	quarter	of	2023, PMI	recorded	a	pre-tax	charge	of	$140	million	commensurate	with	the	early	termination	of	the	pledge	agreement.	The	pre-tax charge	was	recorded	in	marketing,	administration	and	research	costs	in	the	consolidated	statements	of	earnings	for	the year	ended	December	31,	2023	and	was	included	in	the	operating	results	of	the	following	segments:	Europe	($62	million); SSEA,	CIS	&	MEA	($44	million);	EA,	AU	&	PMI	DF	($27	million);	and	Americas	($7	million).
- Saudi	Arabia	customs	assessments -	In	June	2021,	PMI	recorded	a	pre-tax	charge	of	$246	million	in	relation	to	additional customs	 duties	 in	 Saudi	 Arabia	 assessed	 for	 the	 periods	 of	 2014	 through	 2020	 in	 line	 with	 existing	 and	 contemplated arrangements	with	our	distributors.	In	accordance	with	U.S.	GAAP,	the	charge	was	recorded	as	a	reduction	in	net	revenues of	combustible	tobacco	products	included	in	the	SSEA,	CIS	&	MEA	segment	for	the	year	ended	December	31,	2021.
- Asset	acquisition	cost -	See	Note	3. Acquisitions for	the	details	of	the	$51	million	pre-tax	charge	associated	with	the asset	 acquisition	 of	 OtiTopic,	 Inc.	 included	 in	 the	 Wellness	 and	 Healthcare	 segment	 within	 the	 operating	 income	 table above	for	the	year	ended	December	31,	2021.

its	affiliates	into	the	U.S.	The	settlement	also	allows	each	party	to	innovate	and	introduce	product	iterations.	For	further details,	see	Item	8,	Note	18. Contingencies .

## War	in	Ukraine

In	Ukraine,	our	main	priority	remains	the	safety	and	security	of	our	employees	and	their	families	in	the	country.	We	continue commercial	activities	in	select	locations	where	safety	allows,	in	order	to	provide	product	availability	and	service	to	adult consumers,	 and	 supply	 the	 market	 from	 production	 centers	 outside	 Ukraine,	 as	 well	 as	 through	 a	 contract	 manufacturing arrangement.	 Production	 at	 our	 factory	 in	 Kharkiv	 remains	 suspended.	 On	 June	 20,	 2023,	 we	 announced	 the	 investment	 of $30	million	in	a	new	production	facility	in	the	Lviv	region,	in	Western	Ukraine.	Preparatory	work	for	the	facility	began	in July	 2023	 and	 production	 is	 expected	 to	 commence	 in	 the	 first	 quarter	 of	 2024.	 As	 of	 December	 31,	 2023,	 our	 Ukrainian operations	had	approximately	$0.4	billion	in	total	assets,	excluding	intercompany	balances.

In	Russia,	we	are	continuously	assessing	the	evolving	situation	in	the	country.	This	includes	regulatory	constraints	in	the market	entailing	very	complex	terms	and	conditions	that	must	be	met	for	any	divestment	transaction	to	be	granted	approval	by the	 authorities,	 and	 restrictions	 resulting	 from	 international	 regulations.	 In	 the	 event	 of	 a	 divestment,	 our	 ability	 to fully	realize	the	value	of	the	business	would	likely	be	subject	to	material	impairment.	As	of	December	31,	2023,	our	Russian operations	 had	 approximately	 $2.7	 billion	 in	 total	 assets,	 excluding	 intercompany	 balances,	 of	 which	 approximately	 $0.8 billion	consisted	of	cash	and	equivalents	held	mostly	in	local	currency	(Russian	rubles).

Additionally,	we	hold	a	23%	equity	interest	in	Megapolis	Distribution	BV,	the	holding	company	of	CJSC	TK	Megapolis,	PMI's distributor	in	Russia.	For	further	details,	see	Item	8,	Note	6. Related	Parties	-	Equity	Investments	and	Other .

These	developments	above	have	and	will	continue	to	have	a	material	adverse	impact	on	our	business,	results	of	operations, cash	flows	and	financial	position,	and	may	result	in	impairment	charges.

For	further	details,	see	Item	8,	Note	4. War	in	Ukraine to	our	consolidated	financial	statements,	as	well	as	Item	1A. Risk Factors and	the	" Trade	Policy "	section	of	this	Item	7.

## Consolidated	Operating	Results

- Net	Revenues	Net	revenues	of	$35.2	billion	for	the	year	ended	December	31,	2023,	increased	by	$3.4	billion,	or	10.7%, from	 the	 comparable	 2022	 amount.	 The	 change	 in	 our	 net	 revenues	 from	 the	 comparable	 2022	 amount	 was	 driven	 by	 the following	(variances	not	to	scale):

Net	 revenues	 increased	 by	 10.7%,	 including	 the	 impact	 of	 the	 Swedish	 Match	 acquisition	 and	 currency.	 Net	 revenues, excluding	currency	and	acquisitions,	increased	by	7.6%,	mainly	reflecting:	a	favorable	pricing	variance,	primarily	driven by	higher	combustible	tobacco	pricing,	and	favorable	volume/mix,	mainly	driven	by	higher	HTU	volume,	partially	offset	by lower	cigarette	volume.	The	increase	was	partly	offset	by	lower	fees	for	certain	distribution	rights	billed	to	customers in	 certain	 markets	 and	 a	 charge	 to	 net	 revenues	 in	 2023	 of	 $80	 million	 following	 the	 termination	 of	 a	 distribution arrangement	in	the	Middle	East,	both	shown	in	"Other."	The	termination	of	a	distribution	arrangement	in	the	Middle	East	is further	described	in	the	following	" Diluted	Earnings	Per	Share "	discussion.

questions.question: How does the $1,232 million in losses to be amortized for pension plans relate to the $85 million amortization of net losses recognized in earnings for post-employment benefits, and what does this imply about the financial impact of benefit plan accounting across periods?
questions.answer: The $1,232 million in losses to be amortized for pension plans on page 123 indicates the accumulated losses that will be recognized over time, while the $85 million amortization of net losses recognized in earnings for post-employment benefits on page 124 reflects the current year’s portion of those amortized losses being transferred to earnings. This implies that while the pension plan has a significant amount of deferred losses, only a portion is being systematically recognized in earnings each year, which affects the company’s short-term financial performance. The difference highlights the accounting mechanism that spreads long-term pension liabilities across multiple periods, balancing the immediate earnings impact.

Hop 2: Losses to be Amortized → Post-Employment Benefits: The amortization of these losses directly impacts the earnings related to post-employment benefits.
Hop 3: Post-Employment Benefits ← PM(page_124): $85 million is disclosed as the amortization of net losses recognized in earnings for post-employment benefits, showing the current year’s impact.

This divergence implies that while the segment may have had fewer new intangible asset additions or a revaluation of existing ones, it continued to invest heavily in physical infrastructure, pointing to an increase in capital intensity and potentially expanding operational capacity.

questions.question: How does Procter & Gamble's emphasis on Health Care as a high-performing segment with 10% organic sales growth align with their broader strategic focus on organic sales growth as a key non-GAAP performance metric?
questions.answer: Procter & Gamble highlights the Health Care segment as a standout performer with 10% organic sales growth in fiscal 2022, reflecting its strong contribution to the company's overall growth. This aligns with the company's strategic emphasis on organic sales growth, which is defined and disclosed in the Management’s Discussion and Analysis (MD&A) as a core non-GAAP metric used by management to evaluate performance. The MD&A further explains that organic sales growth excludes the impacts of acquisitions, divestitures, and foreign exchange, making it a clean indicator of underlying business performance. The strong 10% growth in Health Care thus represents a key driver within the broader context of the company’s reliance on organic growth to signal sustainable performance trends and strategic success across segments.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: PG(page_36) → Health Care: PG reports that the Health Care segment achieved 10% organic sales growth in fiscal 2022.
Hop 2: Health Care → Organic Sales Growth: The Health Care segment's 10% growth is a specific instance of the broader financial metric 'Organic Sales Growth'.
Hop 3: Organic Sales Growth ← PG(page_18): PG defines and emphasizes Organic Sales Growth as a key non-GAAP performance metric used by management to evaluate sustainable results and trends.

hop_3_rel.chunk_text:
and  should  be  read  in  conjunction  with,  our  Consolidated Financial Statements and accompanying Notes. The MD&A is organized in the following sections:

- Overview
- Summary of 2022 Results
- Economic Conditions and Uncertainties
- Results of Operations
- Segment Results
- Cash Flow, Financial Condition and Liquidity
- Significant Accounting Policies and Estimates
- Other Information

Throughout the MD&A  we  refer  to measures used  by management to evaluate  performance,  including  unit  volume growth, net sales, net earnings, diluted net earnings per share and operating cash flow. We also refer to a number of financial measures  that  are  not  defined  under  accounting  principles generally  accepted  in  the  United  States  of  America  (U.S. GAAP), consisting of organic sales growth, core earnings per share  (Core  EPS),  adjusted  free  cash  flow  and  adjusted  free cash  flow  productivity.  Organic  sales  growth  is  net  sales growth excluding the impacts of acquisitions, divestitures and foreign exchange from year-over-year comparisons. Core EPS is  diluted  net  earnings  per  share  from  continuing  operations excluding  certain  items  that  are  not  judged  to  be  part  of  the Company's  sustainable  results  or  trends.  Adjusted  free  cash flow is operating cash flow less capital spending and transitional tax payments related to the U.S. Tax Act. Adjusted free cash flow productivity is the ratio  of  adjusted  free  cash  flow  to  net  earnings  excluding certain one-time items. We believe these measures provide our investors  with  additional  information  about  our  underlying results  and  trends  as  well  as  insight  to  some  of  the  metrics used  to  evaluate  management. The  explanation  at  the  end  of the MD&A provides more details on the use and the derivation of  these  measures  as  well  as  reconciliations  to  the  most directly comparable U.S. GAAP measures.

Management  also  uses certain market share  and  market consumption  estimates  to  evaluate  performance  relative  to competition  despite  some  limitations  on  the  availability  and comparability of share and consumption information. References to market share and consumption in the MD&A are based on a combination of vendor-purchased traditional brickand-mortar and online data in key markets as well as internal estimates. All market share references represent the percentage of sales of our products in dollar terms on a constant currency basis relative to all product sales in the category.  The Company  measures  quarter  and  fiscal  year-to-date  market shares through the most recent period for which market share data is available, which typically reflects a lag time of one or two  months  as  compared  to  the  end  of  the  reporting  period. Management  also  uses  unit  volume  growth  to  evaluate  and explain drivers of changes in net sales. Organic volume growth reflects  year-over-year  changes  in  unit  volume  excluding  the impacts  of acquisitions, divestitures  and  certain  one-time items, if applicable, and is used to explain changes in organic sales.

## OVERVIEW

Procter  &  Gamble  is  a  global  leader  in  the  fast-moving  consumer  goods  industry,  focused  on  providing  branded  consumer packaged goods of superior quality and value to our consumers around the world. Our products are sold in approximately 180 countries and territories primarily through mass merchandisers, e-commerce (including social commerce) channels, grocery stores, membership club stores, drug stores, department stores, distributors, wholesalers, specialty beauty stores (including airport dutyfree  stores),  high-frequency  stores,  pharmacies,  electronics  stores  and  professional  channels.  We  also  sell  direct  to  individual consumers. We have on-the-ground operations in approximately 70 countries.

Our market environment is highly competitive with global, regional and local competitors. In many of the markets and industry segments  in  which  we  sell  our  products,  we  compete  against  other  branded  products,  as  well  as  retailers'  private-label  brands. Additionally, many of the product segments in which we compete are differentiated by price tiers (referred to as super-premium, premium, mid-tier and value-tier products). We believe we are well positioned in the industry segments and markets in which we operate, often holding a leadership or significant market share position.

## Organizational Structure

Our organizational structure is comprised of Sector Business Units (SBUs), Enterprise Markets (EMs), Corporate Functions (CF) and Global Business Services (GBS).

## Sector Business Units

The Company's ten product categories are organized into five SBUs and five reportable segments (under U.S. GAAP): Beauty; Grooming; Health Care; Fabric & Home Care; and Baby, Feminine & Family Care. The SBUs are responsible for global brand strategy, new product upgrades and innovation, marketing plans and supply chain. They have direct profit responsibility for markets representing the large majority of the Company's sales and earnings (referred to as Focus Markets) and are also responsible for innovation plans, supply plans and operating frameworks to drive growth and value creation in the remaining markets (referred to as Enterprise Markets). Throughout the MD&A, we reference business results by region, which are comprised of North America, Europe, Greater China, Latin America, Asia Pacific and India, Middle East and Africa (IMEA).

questions.question: Given that Baby, Feminine & Family Care had no net sales growth in fiscal 2024 despite contributing to organic sales growth, how might the lack of net sales growth in this segment impact P&G's overall net sales growth of 2%, especially considering that organic sales growth excludes foreign exchange and acquisition/divestiture effects?
questions.answer: Baby, Feminine & Family Care had no net sales growth in fiscal 2024, which contrasts with its contribution of 2% to organic sales growth. This implies that while the segment performed well on an organic basis, the effects of foreign exchange (2% unfavorable impact) and/or acquisitions/divestitures fully offset the organic growth, resulting in zero net sales growth. Since P&G's total net sales growth was 2%, and one of its five major segments contributed nothing to that growth, the burden of growth fell more heavily on the other four segments. This raises questions about the segment's resilience in foreign markets and its strategic positioning within the broader portfolio, especially as P&G prepares to adopt new segment reporting standards that may reveal even more granular performance insights.

## New	Accounting	Pronouncements	and	Policies

In	 November	 2023,	 the	 Financial	 Accounting	 Standards	 Board	 (FASB)	 issued	 Accounting	 Standards	 Update	 (ASU)	 No.	 2023-07, 'Segment	Reporting:	Improvements	to	Reportable	Segment	Disclosures.'	This	guidance	requires	disclosure	of	incremental	segment information	on	an	annual	and	interim	basis.	This	amendment	is	effective	for	our	fiscal	year	ending	June	30,	2025,	and	our interim	periods	within	the	fiscal	year	ending	June	30,	2026.	We	are	currently	assessing	the	impact	of	this	guidance	on	our disclosures.

In	 December	 2023,	 the	 FASB	 issued	 ASU	 No.	 2023-09,	 'Income	 Taxes:	 Improvements	 to	 Income	 Tax	 Disclosures.'	 This	 guidance requires	consistent	categories	and	greater	disaggregation	of	information	in	the	rate	reconciliation	and	disclosures	of	income taxes	paid	by	jurisdiction.	This	amendment	is	effective	for	our	fiscal	year	ending	June	30,	2026.	We	are	currently	assessing the	impact	of	this	guidance	on	our	disclosures.

No	other	new	accounting	pronouncement	issued	or	effective	during	the	fiscal	year	had,	or	is	expected	to	have,	a	material impact	on	our	Consolidated	Financial	Statements.

## NOTE	2

## SEGMENT	INFORMATION

Under	U.S.	GAAP,	our	operating	segments	are	aggregated	into	five	reportable	segments:	1)	Beauty,	2)	Grooming,	3)	Health	Care, 4)	Fabric	&	Home	Care	and	5)	Baby,	Feminine	&	Family	Care.	Our	five	reportable	segments	are	comprised	of:

- Beauty :	 Hair	 Care	 (Conditioners,	 Shampoos,	 Styling	 Aids,	 Treatments);	 Skin	 and	 Personal	 Care	 (Antiperspirants	 and Deodorants,	Personal	Cleansing,	Skin	Care);
- Grooming :	 Grooming	 (Appliances,	 Female	 Blades	 &	 Razors,	 Male	 Blades	 &	 Razors,	 Pre-	 and	 Post-Shave	 Products,	 Other Grooming);
- Health	Care :	Oral	Care	(Toothbrushes,	Toothpaste,	Other	Oral	Care);	Personal	Health	Care	(Gastrointestinal,	Pain	Relief, Rapid	Diagnostics,	Respiratory,	Vitamins/Minerals/Supplements,	Other	Personal	Health	Care);
- Fabric	&	Home	Care :	Fabric	Care	(Fabric	Enhancers,	Laundry	Additives,	Laundry	Detergents);	Home	Care	(Air	Care,	Dish	Care, P&G	Professional,	Surface	Care);	and
- Baby,	 Feminine	 &	 Family	 Care :	 Baby	 Care	 (Baby	 Wipes,	 Taped	 Diapers	 and	 Pants);	 Feminine	 Care	 (Adult	 Incontinence, Menstrual	Care);	Family	Care	(Paper	Towels,	Tissues,	Toilet	Paper).

While	none	of	our	reportable	segments	are	highly	seasonal,	components	within	certain	reportable	segments,	such	as	Appliances (Grooming)	and	Personal	Health	Care	(Health),	are	seasonal.

The	 accounting	 policies	 of	 the	 segments	 are	 generally	 the	 same	 as	 those	 described	 in	 Note	 1.	 Differences	 between	 these policies	and	U.S.	GAAP	primarily	reflect	income	taxes,	which	are	reflected	in	the	segments	using	applicable	blended	statutory rates.	Adjustments	to	arrive	at	our	effective	tax	rate	are	included	in	Corporate.	In	addition,	capital	expenditures	in	the segments	are	on	an	accrual	basis	consistent	with	the	balance	sheet.	Adjustments	to	move	from	an	accrual	to	cash	basis,	for purposes	of	the	cash	flow	statement,	are	reflected	in	Corporate.

Corporate	 includes	 certain	 operating	 and	 non-operating	 activities	 that	 are	 not	 reflected	 in	 the	 operating	 results	 used internally	to	measure	and	evaluate	the	businesses,	as	well	as	items	to	adjust	management	reporting	principles	to	U.S.	GAAP. Operating	 activities	 in	 Corporate	 include	 the	 results	 of	 incidental	 businesses	 managed	 at	 the	 corporate	 level.	 Operating elements	 also	 include	 certain	 employee	 benefit	 costs,	 the	 costs	 of	 certain	 restructuring-type	 activities	 to	 maintain	 a competitive	cost	structure,	including	manufacturing	and	workforce	optimization,	asset	impairment	charges	and	other	general Corporate	 items.	 The	 non-operating	 elements	 in	 Corporate	 primarily	 include	 interest	 expense,	 certain	 pension	 and	 other postretirement	benefit	costs,	certain	acquisition	and	divestiture	gains,	interest	and	investing	income	and	other	financing costs.

Total	assets	for	the	reportable	segments	include	those	assets	managed	by	the	reportable	segment,	primarily	inventory,	fixed assets	 and	 intangible	 assets.	 Other	 assets,	 primarily	 cash,	 accounts	 receivable,	 investment	 securities	 and	 goodwill,	 are included	in	Corporate.

Amounts	in	millions	of	dollars	except	per	share	amounts	or	as	otherwise	specified.

questions.question: How does Target's reported earnings before income taxes of $5.3 billion, including $1.1 billion from foreign entities, reconcile with the EBIT figure of $5.672 billion and the decline in operating income to $5.566 billion across different sections of the 2024 10-K filing?
questions.answer: Target's 2024 10-K filing shows a nuanced financial picture. On page 60, earnings before income taxes are reported at $5.3 billion, with $1.1 billion coming from foreign entities. This figure reflects the company's overall profitability before tax considerations. On page 31, EBIT is disclosed as $5.672 billion, showing a slight decrease of 2.2% from the prior year. This metric includes operating income and interest expenses, providing a broader view of operational efficiency. Moving to page 69, the operating income is detailed at $5.566 billion, indicating a decline from $5.707 billion in the prior year. The slight discrepancy between EBIT and operating income arises because EBIT adjusts for interest expenses and other income, while operating income reflects core business operations. The decline in operating income suggests challenges in maintaining profitability from core operations, despite EBIT remaining relatively stable. This synthesis highlights the importance of understanding how different financial metrics, such as earnings before income taxes, EBIT, and operating income, interrelate and reflect various aspects of the company's financial health.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [TGT](page_60) → [EBIT 2024]: Earnings before income taxes are reported at $5.3 billion, with $1.1 billion from foreign entities, indicating the company's overall profitability before tax considerations.
Hop 2: [EBIT 2024] → [EBIT]: EBIT is disclosed as $5.672 billion, showing a slight decrease of 2.2% from the prior year, providing a broader view of operational efficiency.

Hop 3: [EBIT] ← [TGT](page_69): Operating income is detailed at $5.566 billion, indicating a decline from $5.707 billion in the prior year, reflecting challenges in maintaining profitability from core operations.

questions.question: How does the unfavorable volume/mix in South & Southeast Asia contrast with the favorable volume/mix driven by higher heated tobacco unit volume in Eastern Europe and East Asia & Australia, and what impact does this have on PM's operating income growth in these regions?
questions.answer: In South & Southeast Asia, PM reports unfavorable pricing and volume/mix, along with higher marketing, administration, and research costs, which negatively impacts profitability. In contrast, Eastern Europe experiences favorable volume/mix, lower manufacturing costs, and favorable pricing, while East Asia & Australia sees favorable pricing and lower manufacturing costs, despite higher marketing, administration, and research costs. These favorable trends in Eastern Europe and East Asia & Australia contribute to improved operating income growth. Specifically, in the European Union, favorable volume/mix driven by higher heated tobacco unit volume contributes to a 12.5% increase in operating income, excluding currency and acquisitions. The contrast highlights how regional differences in volume/mix and cost structures significantly affect PM's profitability across markets.

Hop 2: Volume Mix → Heated Tobacco Unit Volume: Favorable volume/mix in Eastern Europe and East Asia & Australia is driven by higher heated tobacco unit volume, particularly in Russia and Ukraine.

Hop 3: Heated Tobacco Unit Volume ← PM(page_53): In the European Union, favorable volume/mix from higher heated tobacco unit volume contributes to a 12.5% increase in operating income, excluding currency and acquisitions.

For  further  details,  see  the Consolidated  Operating  Results and Operating  Results  by  Business  Segment sections  of  the  following Discussion and Analysis .

## IQOS Device Supply

The current global semiconductor shortage has resulted in a tightness in IQOS device  supply  in  the  second  half  of  2021.  In  the  fourth quarter of 2021, the IQOS device supply situation eased, resulting in an improved IQOS user growth versus the third quarter. We expect an improving IQOS device supply situation, with a gradual return to an unconstrained IQOS user quarterly growth progression. However, we still do not have full visibility over the full year 2022.

## IQOS in the United States

On November 29, 2021, an importation ban and cease-and-desist orders imposed by the U.S. International Trade Commission ("ITC") relating  to IQOS Platform  1  products  (including  consumables  and  infringing  components)  went  into  effect.  As  a  result, IQOS is  not currently available for sale in the U.S. We have appealed the patent and statutory issues related to the ITC's Final Determination, and also have contingency plans underway, including domestic production. We hope to be able to resume U.S. supply in the first half of 2023. For more details on the ITC case and related legal matters, please refer to Item 8, Note 17 . Contingencies .

The ITC decision has no bearing outside the U.S.; competitor lawsuits based on the same patent families have repeatedly and universally failed in European courts and the European Patent Office.

## Acquisitions

During 2021, PMI acquired the following companies:

- Vectura Group plc, an inhaled therapeutics company based in the United Kingdom;
- Fertin  Pharma A/S,  a  Danish  company  that  is  a  leading  developer  and  manufacturer  of  innovative  pharmaceutical  and  well-being products based on oral and intra-oral delivery systems;
- OtiTopic,  Inc.,  a  U.S.  respiratory  drug  development  company  with  a  late-stage  dry  powder  inhalation  aspirin  treatment  for  acute myocardial infarction; and
- AG Snus Aktieselskab, a Danish company, and its Swedish subsidiary, Tobacco House of Sweden AB, fully owned by AG Snus, which operates in the oral tobacco and modern oral product categories.

For further details on these acquisitions, see Item 8, Note 6. Acquisitions .

questions.question: What does the Baby, Feminine & Family Care segment's flat reported net sales growth, despite a 2% favorable foreign exchange impact, reveal about its underlying business performance when viewed through the lens of organic sales growth as a non-GAAP metric?
questions.answer: The Baby, Feminine & Family Care segment reported flat net sales growth, but this masks the underlying performance revealed by the organic sales growth metric. Specifically, the segment experienced a 2% favorable foreign exchange impact (as stated in the reconciliation table), yet its organic sales growth was also flat. This indicates that the segment's core business performance—excluding currency and M&A effects—was stagnant year-over-year. The use of organic sales growth as a non-GAAP measure is intended to provide investors with a clearer view of the segment's fundamental trends, suggesting that despite currency tailwinds, the segment did not achieve real growth from its existing operations during the fiscal year.

Hop 2: Organic Sales Growth → Baby, Feminine & Family Care: The segment's organic sales growth was flat, despite a 2% positive foreign exchange impact, indicating that currency adjustments were masking a lack of real growth in the business.

Hop 3: Baby, Feminine & Family Care ← PG(page_44): As one of P&G's five reportable segments under U.S. GAAP, Baby, Feminine & Family Care includes categories like baby wipes, diapers, feminine hygiene, and family paper products, and its performance is evaluated alongside other segments for strategic and operational decision-making.

## NOTE	2

## SEGMENT	INFORMATION

Under	U.S.	GAAP,	our	operating	segments	are	aggregated	into	five	reportable	segments:	1)	Beauty,	2)	Grooming,	3)	Health	Care, 4)	Fabric	&	Home	Care	and	5)	Baby,	Feminine	&	Family	Care.	Our	five	reportable	segments	are	comprised	of:

- Beauty :	 Hair	 Care	 (Conditioners,	 Shampoos,	 Styling	 Aids,	 Treatments);	 Skin	 and	 Personal	 Care	 (Antiperspirants	 and Deodorants,	Personal	Cleansing,	Skin	Care);
- Grooming :	 Grooming	 (Appliances,	 Female	 Blades	 &	 Razors,	 Male	 Blades	 &	 Razors,	 Pre-	 and	 Post-Shave	 Products,	 Other Grooming);
- Health	Care :	Oral	Care	(Toothbrushes,	Toothpaste,	Other	Oral	Care);	Personal	Health	Care	(Gastrointestinal,	Pain	Relief, Rapid	Diagnostics,	Respiratory,	Vitamins/Minerals/Supplements,	Other	Personal	Health	Care);
- Fabric	&	Home	Care :	Fabric	Care	(Fabric	Enhancers,	Laundry	Additives,	Laundry	Detergents);	Home	Care	(Air	Care,	Dish	Care, P&G	Professional,	Surface	Care);	and
- Baby,	 Feminine	 &	 Family	 Care :	 Baby	 Care	 (Baby	 Wipes,	 Taped	 Diapers	 and	 Pants);	 Feminine	 Care	 (Adult	 Incontinence, Menstrual	Care);	Family	Care	(Paper	Towels,	Tissues,	Toilet	Paper).

While	none	of	our	reportable	segments	are	highly	seasonal,	components	within	certain	reportable	segments,	such	as	Appliances (Grooming)	and	Personal	Health	Care	(Health),	are	seasonal.

The	 accounting	 policies	 of	 the	 segments	 are	 generally	 the	 same	 as	 those	 described	 in	 Note	 1.	 Differences	 between	 these policies	and	U.S.	GAAP	primarily	reflect	income	taxes,	which	are	reflected	in	the	segments	using	applicable	blended	statutory rates.	Adjustments	to	arrive	at	our	effective	tax	rate	are	included	in	Corporate.	In	addition,	capital	expenditures	in	the segments	are	on	an	accrual	basis	consistent	with	the	balance	sheet.	Adjustments	to	move	from	an	accrual	to	cash	basis,	for purposes	of	the	cash	flow	statement,	are	reflected	in	Corporate.

Corporate	 includes	 certain	 operating	 and	 non-operating	 activities	 that	 are	 not	 reflected	 in	 the	 operating	 results	 used internally	to	measure	and	evaluate	the	businesses,	as	well	as	items	to	adjust	management	reporting	principles	to	U.S.	GAAP. Operating	 activities	 in	 Corporate	 include	 the	 results	 of	 incidental	 businesses	 managed	 at	 the	 corporate	 level.	 Operating elements	 also	 include	 certain	 employee	 benefit	 costs,	 the	 costs	 of	 certain	 restructuring-type	 activities	 to	 maintain	 a competitive	cost	structure,	including	manufacturing	and	workforce	optimization,	asset	impairment	charges	and	other	general Corporate	 items.	 The	 non-operating	 elements	 in	 Corporate	 primarily	 include	 interest	 expense,	 certain	 pension	 and	 other postretirement	benefit	costs,	certain	acquisition	and	divestiture	gains,	interest	and	investing	income	and	other	financing costs.

Total	assets	for	the	reportable	segments	include	those	assets	managed	by	the	reportable	segment,	primarily	inventory,	fixed assets	 and	 intangible	 assets.	 Other	 assets,	 primarily	 cash,	 accounts	 receivable,	 investment	 securities	 and	 goodwill,	 are included	in	Corporate.

Amounts	in	millions	of	dollars	except	per	share	amounts	or	as	otherwise	specified.

questions.question: How does the $24 million post-retirement benefit loss in other comprehensive earnings relate to the $16 million amount being amortized for post-retirement benefits?
questions.answer: The $24 million post-retirement benefit loss in other comprehensive earnings (reported on page 124) reflects the current year's unfavorable changes in post-retirement benefit obligations. This loss contributes to the accumulated net losses that are then amortized over time. On page 123, we see that $16 million of post-retirement benefit losses are included in the total $2,589 million of losses to be amortized. The prior service cost (credit) of $1 million for post-retirement benefits on page 123 further indicates adjustments being made to align benefit obligations with financial reporting standards. Together, these figures demonstrate how the company accounts for and systematically amortizes post-retirement benefit losses over time.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: PM(page_124) → Post-Retirement Benefits: The company reports a $24 million loss in other comprehensive earnings related to post-retirement benefits.
Hop 2: Post-Retirement Benefits → Prior Service Cost (Credit): The prior service cost (credit) of $1 million indicates adjustments to align benefit obligations with financial reporting standards.

Hop 3: Prior Service Cost (Credit) ← PM(page_123): The company discloses $16 million in post-retirement benefit losses to be amortized, showing how these losses are systematically recognized in earnings.

questions.question: Given Fabric & Home Care's 8% organic sales growth in fiscal 2022, how does its contribution to Procter & Gamble's Earnings Before Income Taxes compare to its growth performance, and what does this imply about the segment's profitability efficiency?
questions.answer: Fabric & Home Care achieved 8% organic sales growth in fiscal 2022, reflecting strong top-line performance. However, its Earnings Before Income Taxes for the same period stood at $5,729 million, representing a decline from $5,986 million in fiscal 2021. This indicates that while the segment grew sales significantly, its profitability contribution to P&G weakened year-over-year. This divergence suggests potential margin pressures or rising costs within the segment that offset the benefits of higher sales growth, thereby reducing its overall profitability efficiency.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: PG(page_36) → Fabric & Home Care: Organic Sales Growth of 8% in fiscal 2022
Hop 2: Fabric & Home Care → Earnings/(Loss) Before Income Taxes: Segment's EBIT decreased from $5,986M in 2021 to $5,729M in 2022
Hop 3: Earnings/(Loss) Before Income Taxes ← PG(page_50): Segment-level EBIT figures disclosed in the Global Segment Results table

questions.question: How does QFNA's $2 million employee compensation expense compare with its consistent 1% allocation of corporate unallocated expenses over the past three years, and what does this suggest about its relative operational scale compared to other business segments?
questions.answer: QFNA consistently represents just 1% of corporate unallocated expenses across 2019–2021, and in 2021, it accounted for only $2 million (1.56%) of the company's total $128 million employee compensation expense. This low proportion in both cost categories indicates that QFNA operates at a significantly smaller scale compared to other segments like LatAm ($64 million total expenses, including $44 million in employee compensation) or FLNA ($56 million total, $35 million in employee compensation). The alignment between its minimal cost footprint and its low allocation of corporate expenses suggests QFNA is a minor contributor to overall operations, both in terms of workforce size and strategic resource allocation.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: PEP(page_72) → QFNA: QFNA is reported to account for a consistent 1% of corporate unallocated expenses from 2019 to 2021.

Hop 2: QFNA → Employee Compensation Expense: In 2021, QFNA’s employee compensation expense was $2 million, representing a small fraction of the company-wide $128 million in total employee compensation expense.

Hop 3: Employee Compensation Expense ← PEP(page_74): The detailed expense breakdown by segment shows QFNA’s $2 million employee compensation expense is significantly lower than other segments, reinforcing its smaller operational scale.

questions.question: How does PepsiCo's capital spending allocation for the AMESA segment in 2024 compare with its pension and retiree benefits expense allocation for the same segment, and what might this suggest about the company's strategic resource prioritization?
questions.answer: In 2024, PepsiCo allocated $450 million in capital spending to the AMESA segment, reflecting a focus on infrastructure and growth initiatives in the region. In contrast, the company's pension and retiree benefits expense allocation for AMESA in 2024 was only $14 million, indicating a much smaller financial commitment to legacy obligations in the same region. This disparity suggests that PepsiCo is prioritizing growth and operational expansion over legacy cost burdens in AMESA, potentially signaling confidence in the region's future profitability and strategic importance.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: PEP(page_76) → Capital Spending: PepsiCo discloses $450 million in capital spending for the AMESA segment in 2024.
Hop 2: Capital Spending → AMESA: Capital spending is specifically itemized by segment, with AMESA being one of the geographic regions.
Hop 3: AMESA ← PEP(page_82): PepsiCo reports $14 million in pension and retiree benefits expense for the AMESA segment in 2024.

questions.question: Given Home Care's consistent 12% revenue contribution over the past three fiscal years, how does P&G's decision to report it within the broader Fabric & Home Care segment affect visibility into its standalone performance trends?
questions.answer: P&G reports Home Care as a component of the broader Fabric & Home Care segment, which includes Fabric Care products like laundry detergents and fabric enhancers. While Home Care has consistently contributed 12% of total sales over the past three fiscal years (2022–2024), its performance is aggregated with Fabric Care in the segment reporting structure. This aggregation limits detailed visibility into Home Care's individual growth, profitability, or operational performance, especially compared to standalone segments like Grooming or Oral Care. As a result, stakeholders must infer Home Care's trajectory from limited disclosures rather than direct segment-level financials, potentially obscuring specific opportunities or risks within this category.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: PG(page_45) → Home Care: Home Care's revenue contribution is consistently reported at 12% across 2022, 2023, and 2024 fiscal years.

Hop 2: Home Care → Fabric & Home Care: Home Care is explicitly grouped under the broader Fabric & Home Care segment, which also includes Fabric Care subcategories such as laundry additives and detergents.

Hop 3: Fabric & Home Care ← PG(page_44): Segment-level disclosures for Fabric & Home Care do not differentiate performance metrics between Fabric Care and Home Care, limiting granular visibility into the latter’s operational or financial trends.

## New	Accounting	Pronouncements	and	Policies

In	 November	 2023,	 the	 Financial	 Accounting	 Standards	 Board	 (FASB)	 issued	 Accounting	 Standards	 Update	 (ASU)	 No.	 2023-07, 'Segment	Reporting:	Improvements	to	Reportable	Segment	Disclosures.'	This	guidance	requires	disclosure	of	incremental	segment information	on	an	annual	and	interim	basis.	This	amendment	is	effective	for	our	fiscal	year	ending	June	30,	2025,	and	our interim	periods	within	the	fiscal	year	ending	June	30,	2026.	We	are	currently	assessing	the	impact	of	this	guidance	on	our disclosures.

In	 December	 2023,	 the	 FASB	 issued	 ASU	 No.	 2023-09,	 'Income	 Taxes:	 Improvements	 to	 Income	 Tax	 Disclosures.'	 This	 guidance requires	consistent	categories	and	greater	disaggregation	of	information	in	the	rate	reconciliation	and	disclosures	of	income taxes	paid	by	jurisdiction.	This	amendment	is	effective	for	our	fiscal	year	ending	June	30,	2026.	We	are	currently	assessing the	impact	of	this	guidance	on	our	disclosures.

No	other	new	accounting	pronouncement	issued	or	effective	during	the	fiscal	year	had,	or	is	expected	to	have,	a	material impact	on	our	Consolidated	Financial	Statements.

## NOTE	2

- Beauty :	 Hair	 Care	 (Conditioners,	 Shampoos,	 Styling	 Aids,	 Treatments);	 Skin	 and	 Personal	 Care	 (Antiperspirants	 and Deodorants,	Personal	Cleansing,	Skin	Care);
- Grooming :	 Grooming	 (Appliances,	 Female	 Blades	 &	 Razors,	 Male	 Blades	 &	 Razors,	 Pre-	 and	 Post-Shave	 Products,	 Other Grooming);
- Health	Care :	Oral	Care	(Toothbrushes,	Toothpaste,	Other	Oral	Care);	Personal	Health	Care	(Gastrointestinal,	Pain	Relief, Rapid	Diagnostics,	Respiratory,	Vitamins/Minerals/Supplements,	Other	Personal	Health	Care);
- Fabric	&	Home	Care :	Fabric	Care	(Fabric	Enhancers,	Laundry	Additives,	Laundry	Detergents);	Home	Care	(Air	Care,	Dish	Care, P&G	Professional,	Surface	Care);	and
- Baby,	 Feminine	 &	 Family	 Care :	 Baby	 Care	 (Baby	 Wipes,	 Taped	 Diapers	 and	 Pants);	 Feminine	 Care	 (Adult	 Incontinence, Menstrual	Care);	Family	Care	(Paper	Towels,	Tissues,	Toilet	Paper).

While	none	of	our	reportable	segments	are	highly	seasonal,	components	within	certain	reportable	segments,	such	as	Appliances (Grooming)	and	Personal	Health	Care	(Health),	are	seasonal.

The	 accounting	 policies	 of	 the	 segments	 are	 generally	 the	 same	 as	 those	 described	 in	 Note	 1.	 Differences	 between	 these policies	and	U.S.	GAAP	primarily	reflect	income	taxes,	which	are	reflected	in	the	segments	using	applicable	blended	statutory rates.	Adjustments	to	arrive	at	our	effective	tax	rate	are	included	in	Corporate.	In	addition,	capital	expenditures	in	the segments	are	on	an	accrual	basis	consistent	with	the	balance	sheet.	Adjustments	to	move	from	an	accrual	to	cash	basis,	for purposes	of	the	cash	flow	statement,	are	reflected	in	Corporate.

Corporate	 includes	 certain	 operating	 and	 non-operating	 activities	 that	 are	 not	 reflected	 in	 the	 operating	 results	 used internally	to	measure	and	evaluate	the	businesses,	as	well	as	items	to	adjust	management	reporting	principles	to	U.S.	GAAP. Operating	 activities	 in	 Corporate	 include	 the	 results	 of	 incidental	 businesses	 managed	 at	 the	 corporate	 level.	 Operating elements	 also	 include	 certain	 employee	 benefit	 costs,	 the	 costs	 of	 certain	 restructuring-type	 activities	 to	 maintain	 a competitive	cost	structure,	including	manufacturing	and	workforce	optimization,	asset	impairment	charges	and	other	general Corporate	 items.	 The	 non-operating	 elements	 in	 Corporate	 primarily	 include	 interest	 expense,	 certain	 pension	 and	 other postretirement	benefit	costs,	certain	acquisition	and	divestiture	gains,	interest	and	investing	income	and	other	financing costs.

Total	assets	for	the	reportable	segments	include	those	assets	managed	by	the	reportable	segment,	primarily	inventory,	fixed assets	 and	 intangible	 assets.	 Other	 assets,	 primarily	 cash,	 accounts	 receivable,	 investment	 securities	 and	 goodwill,	 are included	in	Corporate.

questions.question: How does the 2% negative foreign exchange impact on Fabric & Home Care net sales growth relate to the segment's $27.6 billion revenue base and its 8% organic sales growth performance?
questions.answer: The 2% negative foreign exchange impact on Fabric & Home Care net sales growth, as shown in the consolidated net sales table, reduces the segment's overall growth from what would otherwise have been achieved organically. Despite this headwind, the segment still achieved an 8% organic sales growth, which indicates strong underlying performance driven by volume and pricing initiatives. Given the segment's $27.6 billion revenue base, the foreign exchange headwind likely represents a meaningful dollar amount that offset the full potential of reported sales growth. This contrast highlights how currency fluctuations constrain top-line growth even when operational performance is robust.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: PG(page_36) → Fabric & Home Care: Segment net sales growth is reported at 6%, with foreign exchange impact quantified at 2% negative.
Hop 2: Fabric & Home Care → Foreign Exchange: The segment's performance is explicitly adjusted downward due to unfavorable foreign exchange movements.

Hop 3: Foreign Exchange ← PG(page_28): The detailed segment commentary confirms the $27.6 billion revenue base and 8% organic growth, contextualizing the FX impact within the segment's overall performance.

hop_3_rel.chunk_text:
Fabric & Home Care net sales increased 6% to $27.6 billion in fiscal  2022  on  a  3%  increase  in  unit  volume.  Unfavorable foreign  exchange  decreased  net  sales  by  2%.  Higher  pricing increased  net  sales  by  5%.  Mix  had  a  neutral  impact  to  net sales. Organic sales increased 8%. Global market share of the Fabric & Home Care segment increased 1.5 points.

- Fabric  Care  net  sales  increased  high  single  digits.  The positive impacts of a mid-single digit increase in volume, increased  pricing,  increased  trade  spend  efficiencies  and positive mix (due to the disproportionate growth in North America  and  growth  of  fabric  enhancers  and  premium forms,  all  of  which  have  higher  than  category-average selling prices) were partially offset by unfavorable foreign exchange. Organic sales increased double digits. Volume increased high single digits in North  America and increased  low  single  digits  in  Asia  Pacific,  both  due  to market growth and innovation. Global market share of the fabric care category increased more than a point.
- Home Care net sales were unchanged. Negative impacts of a  low  single  digit  decrease  in  volume,  increased  trade spending and unfavorable foreign exchange were offset by increased  pricing.  Organic  sales  increased  low  single digits.  V olume  decreased  20%  in  IMEA  (due  to  market contraction  and  competitive  activity)  and  decreased  low single digits in North America (due to market contraction versus  a  prior  year  that  benefited  from  pandemic-related consumption increases). Global market share of the home care category increased more than a point.

Net earnings decreased 5% to $4.4 billion in fiscal 2022 as the increase in net sales was more than offset by a 190 basis-point reduction in net earnings margin. Net earnings margin decreased  due  primarily  to  a  reduction  in  gross  margin, partially offset by a reduction in SG&A as a percentage of net sales. The gross margin decrease was primarily driven by  an  increase  in  commodity  and  transportation  costs,  and unfavorable  mix  caused  by  the  growth  of  premium-priced, profit-accretive products that have lower than segmentaverage  gross  margins,  partially  offset  by  increased  pricing. SG&A as a percentage of net sales declined due to the positive scale  benefits  of  the  net  sales  increase  and  a  reduction  in marketing spending.

## BABY, FEMININE & FAMILY CARE

questions.question: What percentage of PepsiCo's 2024 expected pre-tax charges allocated to FLNA is reflected in the 2024 pension and retiree benefits expense for that segment, and how does this compare to the cumulative spending plan to date for FLNA?
questions.answer: PepsiCo allocated 15% of its expected pre-tax charges to FLNA in 2024. The 2024 pension and retiree benefits expense for FLNA is $150 million, which is part of a cumulative spending plan to date of $402 million for that segment. This indicates that the current year's pension expense represents approximately 37.3% of the total historical spending allocated to FLNA, suggesting a significant ongoing commitment to fulfilling long-term obligations in this segment.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: PEP(page_81) → Expected Pre-Tax Charges: PEP discloses that 15% of expected pre-tax charges are allocated to FLNA.
Hop 2: Expected Pre-Tax Charges → FLNA: FLNA is one of the segments to which a portion of the company's expected pre-tax charges is attributed.
Hop 3: FLNA ← PEP(page_82): PEP reports $150 million as the 2024 pension and retiree benefits expense for FLNA, with a cumulative spending plan to date of $402 million.

questions.question: How does the decline in AMESA's acquisition and divestiture-related charges from $10 million in 2021 to $2 million in 2023 align with the relatively stable depreciation and other amortization expenses in the AMESA segment, which remained around $170 million annually over the same period?
questions.answer: The decline in AMESA's acquisition and divestiture-related charges from $10 million in 2021 to $2 million in 2023, as disclosed in the Corporate section (page 112), indicates reduced M&A activity or related costs in recent years. However, the depreciation and other amortization expenses for AMESA remained stable at $167 million in 2023, $179 million in 2022, and $181 million in 2021 (page 75), suggesting that the segment continues to carry a consistent level of long-term asset base or intangible assets from prior periods. This contrast implies that while recent transactional activity has slowed, the historical investments or asset base in AMESA continue to generate steady depreciation and amortization expenses, which may reflect ongoing operational infrastructure or long-lived assets.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: PEP(page_112) → AMESA: Discloses acquisition and divestiture-related charges for AMESA at $2 million in 2023, down from $10 million in 2021
Hop 2: AMESA → Depreciation and Other Amortization: AMESA's depreciation and amortization expenses remain stable across 2021–2023 despite declining M&A charges
Hop 3: Depreciation and Other Amortization ← PEP(page_75): Depreciation and other amortization for AMESA is consistently around $170 million annually, indicating sustained asset base

questions.question: Based on P&G's segment reporting, how does the profitability of Home Care products compare to Fabric Care within the combined Fabric & Home Care segment, and what does this suggest about the relative margin performance of these sub-categories?

Within this segment, Home Care products consistently represent 12% of net sales, while Fabric Care contributes 23% of net sales. Given that the segment’s earnings contribution (31%) is less than its sales contribution (35%), and assuming similar operating costs across sub-segments, Home Care likely has lower margins than Fabric Care. This implies that while both sub-segments contribute to the overall performance, Fabric Care may be more profitable on a per-dollar-sold basis.

However, in Argentina and Colombia, PM experienced a favorable pricing variance for combustible products, which contributed to a 5.6% increase in net revenues excluding currency and acquisitions. This regional divergence in pricing performance highlights the mixed market conditions and pricing power PM experienced across different geographies in 2022.

questions.question: How does the negative impact of foreign exchange on Baby, Feminine & Family Care's net sales growth reconcile with the segment's reported organic growth of 6%, and what does this reveal about the underlying volume and pricing dynamics?
questions.answer: The Baby, Feminine & Family Care segment reported a 5% net sales growth, with foreign exchange negatively impacting growth by 1%. This aligns with the segment's organic sales growth of 6%, indicating that the underlying business strength came from pricing increases (+4%) and modest volume growth (+1%). Despite the drag from foreign exchange, the segment achieved positive organic growth through pricing and mix improvements. This dynamic is consistent with the broader pattern seen in other segments, where unfavorable foreign exchange acted as a headwind but was offset by pricing and volume gains.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: PG(page_36) → Baby, Feminine &Family Care: The segment reports 5% net sales growth and 6% organic sales growth, with foreign exchange listed as a negative factor.
Hop 2: Baby, Feminine &Family Care → Foreign Exchange: Foreign exchange had a -1% impact on net sales growth, as detailed in the breakdown of sales drivers.

Hop 3: Foreign Exchange ← PG(page_28): The discussion on foreign exchange as a headwind is reiterated in the broader context of segment performance, particularly in Fabric & Home Care, where it also acted as a drag on net sales.

hop_3_rel.chunk_text:
Fabric & Home Care net sales increased 6% to $27.6 billion in fiscal  2022  on  a  3%  increase  in  unit  volume.  Unfavorable foreign  exchange  decreased  net  sales  by  2%.  Higher  pricing increased  net  sales  by  5%.  Mix  had  a  neutral  impact  to  net sales. Organic sales increased 8%. Global market share of the Fabric & Home Care segment increased 1.5 points.

- Fabric  Care  net  sales  increased  high  single  digits.  The positive impacts of a mid-single digit increase in volume, increased  pricing,  increased  trade  spend  efficiencies  and positive mix (due to the disproportionate growth in North America  and  growth  of  fabric  enhancers  and  premium forms,  all  of  which  have  higher  than  category-average selling prices) were partially offset by unfavorable foreign exchange. Organic sales increased double digits. Volume increased high single digits in North  America and increased  low  single  digits  in  Asia  Pacific,  both  due  to market growth and innovation. Global market share of the fabric care category increased more than a point.
- Home Care net sales were unchanged. Negative impacts of a  low  single  digit  decrease  in  volume,  increased  trade spending and unfavorable foreign exchange were offset by increased  pricing.  Organic  sales  increased  low  single digits.  V olume  decreased  20%  in  IMEA  (due  to  market contraction  and  competitive  activity)  and  decreased  low single digits in North America (due to market contraction versus  a  prior  year  that  benefited  from  pandemic-related consumption increases). Global market share of the home care category increased more than a point.

Net earnings decreased 5% to $4.4 billion in fiscal 2022 as the increase in net sales was more than offset by a 190 basis-point reduction in net earnings margin. Net earnings margin decreased  due  primarily  to  a  reduction  in  gross  margin, partially offset by a reduction in SG&A as a percentage of net sales. The gross margin decrease was primarily driven by  an  increase  in  commodity  and  transportation  costs,  and unfavorable  mix  caused  by  the  growth  of  premium-priced, profit-accretive products that have lower than segmentaverage  gross  margins,  partially  offset  by  increased  pricing. SG&A as a percentage of net sales declined due to the positive scale  benefits  of  the  net  sales  increase  and  a  reduction  in marketing spending.

questions.question: How does the 4% growth in concentrate sales within the Global Ventures segment reconcile with the overall 12% decline in KO's operating income, despite favorable pricing initiatives?
questions.answer: The 4% growth in concentrate sales within the Global Ventures segment, as reported in the performance metrics, indicates positive volume and pricing momentum in this business area. However, this growth was insufficient to offset broader pressures on KO's profitability, including higher commodity costs, increased selling, general and administrative expenses, and a significant 11% unfavorable foreign currency exchange rate impact on operating income. While favorable pricing initiatives did help partially counteract these declines, the overall operating income still fell by $1,319 million, or 12%, suggesting that the benefits from Global Ventures' concentrate sales growth were overwhelmed by systemic cost and currency headwinds.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: KO(page_51) → Global Ventures: KO's Global Ventures segment experienced an 11% favorable impact from foreign exchange due to a weaker U.S. dollar against certain currencies, which helped cushion the overall 12% decline in operating income.
Hop 2: Global Ventures → Concentrate Sales: The Global Ventures segment reported a 4% increase in concentrate sales, indicating strong performance in this area.

Hop 3: Concentrate Sales ← KO(page_47): Despite this 4% growth in concentrate sales and favorable pricing initiatives, KO's consolidated operating income still declined by 12%, driven by higher commodity costs, increased SG&A expenses, and a significant foreign exchange headwind in other segments.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text:
*    Calculation is not meaning ful.

Operating income was $9,992 million in 2024, compared to $11,311 million in 2023, a decrease of $1,319 million, or 12%. The decrease in operating income was primarily driven by higher commodity costs; higher selling, general and administrative expenses; higher other operating charges; the impact of refranchising our bottling operations in the Philippines, Bangladesh and certain territories in India; and an unfavorable foreign currency exchange rate impact of 11%. These items were partially offset by concentrate sales volume growth of 2% and favorable pricing initiatives.

The decrease in our operating margin on a consolidated basis was primarily due to higher commodity costs; higher selling, general and administrative expenses; higher other operating charges; and an unfavorable foreign currency exchange rate impact. The impact of these items was partially offset by favorable pricing initiatives and the impact of refranchising our bottling operations in the Philippines, Bangladesh and certain territories in India.

In 2024, fluctuations in foreign currency ex change rates unfavorably impacted consolidated operating income by 11% due to a stronger U.S. dollar compared to certain foreign currencies, including the Argentine peso, Mexican peso, Brazilian real, Zimbabwean dollar, Turkish lira, Nigerian naira and Japanese yen, which had an unfavorable impact on our Latin America; Europe, Middle East and Africa; and Asia Pacific operating segments. The unfavorable impact of a stronger U.S. dollar compared to the currencies listed above was partially offset by the impact of a weaker U.S. dollar compared to certain other foreign currencies, including the euro and British pound, which had a favorable impact on our Europe, Middle East and Africa and Global Ventures operating segments. Refer to the heading 'Liquidity, Capital Resources and Financial Position - Foreign Exchange' below.

questions.question: How does the inclusion of prepaid pension assets within unallocated assets impact MDLZ's consolidated asset presentation, given the increase in prepaid pension assets from $672 million in 2020 to $1,009 million in 2021 and their centralized treatment in financial reporting?
questions.answer: MDLZ reports that unallocated assets include prepaid pension assets, which increased significantly from $672 million in 2020 to $1,009 million in 2021. These assets are not reflected in segment-level reporting and are instead managed centrally, along with other unallocated items like deferred taxes and derivatives. This centralized treatment means that the growth in prepaid pension assets contributes to the overall consolidated asset base but is not visible in individual segment asset disclosures, thereby affecting how investors assess asset allocation and pension-related liquidity across the business structure.

Hop 3: Prepaid Pension Assets ← MDLZ(page_116): MDLZ provides quantitative data showing a significant increase in prepaid pension assets from $672 million (2020) to $1,009 million (2021), highlighting a material change in this asset category.

questions.answer: Procter & Gamble's Health Care segment had $7,718 million in net assets at the end of fiscal year 2023 (page 49), and it achieved 5% Organic Sales Growth (page 32), which excludes foreign exchange, acquisitions, and divestitures. The company defines Organic Sales Growth as a non-GAAP metric used to assess underlying sales trends and evaluate management performance for at-risk compensation. This dual perspective shows that while Health Care is a significant asset holder, its performance is also directly tied to a key strategic metric that influences executive incentives, indicating alignment between segment performance and corporate governance objectives.

questions.question: How does the declining contribution of the LatAm segment to total revenue correlate with the trend in depreciation and other amortization expenses specific to that region over the same period?
questions.answer: The LatAm segment's contribution to total revenue declined from 7% in 2019 to 5% in 2021, indicating a shrinking regional presence. During the same period, depreciation and other amortization expenses for LatAm fluctuated but showed a net decline from $270 million in 2019 to $283 million in 2021, which is inconsistent with the revenue trend. This suggests that despite lower revenue contribution, capital investments or asset bases in LatAm remained relatively high, potentially signaling underutilized assets or ongoing infrastructure investments not yet reflected in revenue performance.

questions.answer: The $1 million in amortized losses from post-retirement benefits recognized in the earnings section (page 124) represents the portion of post-retirement benefit losses that were actually charged to earnings during the reporting period. This amount is significantly lower than the $16 million in total losses to be amortized disclosed in the post-retirement benefits rollforward (page 123), which indicates that only a small portion of the total unrecognized losses are being systematically recognized each year. The difference highlights the accounting treatment where losses are amortized over time rather than recognized immediately, reflecting a gradual recognition of actuarial losses that have accumulated in prior periods.

questions.question: How does the capital spending allocation for FLNA in 2024 compare to its depreciation and other amortization expenses, and what might this suggest about the segment's asset utilization and investment strategy?
questions.answer: In 2024, FLNA reported capital spending of $1,182 million and depreciation and other amortization expenses of $806 million. This indicates that FLNA is investing more in new capital than it is depreciating existing assets, suggesting a growth-oriented investment strategy focused on expanding or upgrading its asset base. The difference between these figures ($376 million) implies that FLNA is not only maintaining its current asset infrastructure but also expanding it, which could signal long-term growth plans for the segment.

Hop 3: Depreciation and Other Amortization ← PEP(page_76): The detailed breakdown on page 76 shows FLNA's capital spending of $1,182 million in 2024, which is significantly higher than its depreciation and amortization expense, suggesting active investment in new assets.

questions.question: How does the $14 million actual pre-tax charge recorded for AMESA in 2024 compare to its 5% allocation from the total expected pre-tax charges, and what might this indicate about the accuracy of PEP's regional charge distribution methodology?
questions.answer: The $14 million actual pre-tax charge recorded for AMESA in 2024 represents a relatively small portion of the total $698 million in pre-tax charges for that year. However, AMESA was allocated only 5% of the expected pre-tax charges as disclosed in the regional breakdown. This suggests that the actual charge recorded for AMESA aligns closely with its allocated percentage, indicating that PEP's regional distribution methodology may have been reasonably accurate for this segment. In comparison, Europe was allocated 25% and recorded $123 million, and FLNA was allocated 15% and recorded $150 million, showing similar alignment. Therefore, while the AMESA charge is proportionally low, it does not appear to deviate significantly from expectations when compared to other segments.

Hop 3: [AMESA] ← [PEP](page_82): PEP reports that AMESA incurred $14 million in actual pre-tax charges in 2024, which corresponds closely to its 5% allocation.

questions.question: How does Procter & Gamble's organic sales growth performance in the Fabric & Home Care segment compare with its overall net sales growth, and what does this suggest about the segment's contribution to the company's financial strategy?
questions.answer: Procter & Gamble's overall net sales growth for fiscal 2024 was 2%, driven by 4% pricing increases, partially offset by a 2% unfavorable foreign exchange impact. Within this, the Fabric & Home Care segment reported 4% net sales growth, with only a 1% foreign exchange impact, resulting in 5% organic sales growth. This indicates that the Fabric & Home Care segment outperformed the company average in terms of organic growth, suggesting it played a key role in driving the company's financial momentum. As one of the five core reportable segments, Fabric & Home Care includes product categories such as Fabric Enhancers, Laundry Additives, and Home Care products like Air Care and Surface Care, which appear to be contributing meaningfully to P&G’s growth strategy despite macroeconomic headwinds.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: PG(page_22) → Net Sales Growth: Discloses 2% total net sales growth driven by pricing, with segment-level detail showing mid-single-digit growth in Fabric & Home Care.
Hop 2: Net Sales Growth → Fabric & Home Care: The segment-specific data shows 4% net sales growth and 5% organic sales growth, outpacing the company-wide average.
Hop 3: Fabric & Home Care ← PG(page_44): The segment is defined and categorized in detail, including its major product lines and its role in the company’s broader financial reporting structure.

For	a	detailed	discussion	of	the	fiscal	2023	year-over-year	changes,	please	refer	to	the	MD&A	in	Part	II,	Item	7	of	the Company's	Form	10-K	for	the	fiscal	year	ended	June	30,	2023.

## Net	Sales

Net	 sales	 increased	 2%	 to	 $84.0	 billion	 in	 fiscal	 2024.	 The	 increase	 in	 net	 sales	 was	 driven	 by	 higher	 pricing	 of	 4%, partially	offset	by	unfavorable	foreign	exchange	of	2%.	Volume	and	mix	were	unchanged	versus	the	prior	year.

Net	sales	increased	mid-single	digits	in	Health	Care,	Fabric	&	Home	Care	and	Grooming	and	increased	low	single	digits	in Beauty.	Net	sales	were	unchanged	in	Baby,	Feminine	&	Family	Care.	Organic	sales,	which	exclude	the	impacts	of	acquisitions and	 divestitures	 and	 foreign	 exchange,	 increased	 4%.	 Organic	 sales	 increased	 high	 single	 digits	 in	 Grooming,	 mid-single digits	in	Fabric	&	Home	Care	and	Health	Care	and	low	single	digits	in	Beauty	and	Baby,	Feminine	&	Family	Care.
